physDesc.p: This letter is three pages long. On the first page, the words “Poetry Monroe” are written in pencil at the top. The third page also has, typed, H.M. in the top left corner, and the date (10/25/15) in the top right corner, as well as a -2- in the middle. There is also a black dot on each page near the bottom that looks like it could be from a hole punch.

div.p: I did not for a moment wish to force myself upon your notice for an honorable mention. It never occurred to me that I could influence your judgment; in fact, I know perfectly well that I could not, and so do you. I merely thought it would be an agreeable way of getting out of the difficulty for me, and spoke of it accordingly. One of the things I have always so greatly admired about you is that you "e;gang your ane gait"e; quite regardless of suggestions. So if you do not feel like giving me an honorable mention, why do not do it, my Dear, that is all.
Alice Henderson writes me that she will be here to-day or to-morrow, and I shall be very glad indeed to see her. I am anxiously awaiting a telephone from her to say that she has reached the town.

Fletcher has got here, as you know. He came out to see me last night, and among other things told me that Richard had [sentence cut off] [given you a copy]
of Remy de Courmont &aphos;s "e;aints of Paradise,"e; telling you it was an authorized translation. I have not the slightest doubt that De Gourmont authorized Richard to translate it, but here is an awkward position. Alfred Vallette, who is as you know editor and manager of the Mercure de France, gave Macmillan permission last Sprint for me to use anything I pleased from any of their publications in my forthcoming book "e;Six French Poets."e; Now I have quoted the Dedication of the "e;Saints of Paradise"e; and the poems of four of the saints: Agatha, Colette, Jeanne d&aphos;Arc, and Ursula, in my text in French and translated them with all the other translations in an appendix. I think you should know this. It may not in the least interfere with your accepting Richard&aphos;s translation; and I do not in the least want it to; only as my book will be out within two weeks or so, it will prevent "e;Poetry"e; from having the first translation.

I have had a long struggle in my own mind between my loyalty to Richard in keeping still and letting his translation go through, and
you were not getting exactly what you thought. Richard does not, of course, know what poems I am translating, so this idea of our clashing naturally never entered his head. And please remember, if you do accept Richard&aphos;s translations, that I do not mind at all.

I doubt very much whether Remy de Gourmont possessed the right to authorize translations. He was, I think, a member of the Mercure de France Company; but I know that Macmillian wrote to Vallette rather than to him, although I was in communication with De Gourmont during the time and he himself sent him his portrait for reproduction. Of course, the "e;Saints of Paradise"e; is not a very new book, as it was originally published in 1898, and reprinted in Divertissement [s] in 1914.
